If it had been bought dear, we shouldn't have had permission to return it on his hands. Whatever profit there is, it's proper to bring it home. It don't, now-a-days, befit men to be showing compassion.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I' faith, you are losing time while you are talking. Follow me.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Be it so.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: to THEUROPIDES. I'll give you my services. Pointing. There's the old gentleman. To SIMO. Well now, I've brought you this person.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm glad that you've arrived safely from abroad, Theuropides.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: May the Gods bless you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Your servant was telling me that you were desirous to look over this house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Unless it's inconvenient to you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Oh no; quite convenient. Do step in-doors and look over it.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: pausing. But yet--the ladies----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Take you care not to trouble yourself a straw about any lady. Walk in every direction, wherever you like, all over the house just as though it were your own.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: apart to TRANIO. "Just as though----?"

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: whispering. Oh, take care that you don't throw it in his teeth now in his concern, that you have bought it. Don't you see him, how sad a countenance the old gentleman has?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: apart. I see. TRA. apart. Then don't seem to exult, and to be overmuch delighted; in fact, don't make mention that you've bought it.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: apart. I understand; and I think you've given good advice, and that it shows a humane disposition. Turning to SIMO. What now?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Won't you go in? Look over it at your leisure, just as you like.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I consider that you are acting civilly and kindly.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Troth, I wish to do so. Should you like some one to show you over.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Away with any one to showAway with any one to show: He says this, not liking the mention of the word "perductor," which, beside meaning an "attendant" or "one to escort," signifies a "pander" or "procurer." So in the next line, "perducto" means "to show over" or "to act the procurer" me over. I don't want him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I'll go wrong, rather than any one should show me over.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: pointing. Don't you see, this vestibule before the house, and the piazza, of what a compass it is?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Troth, really handsome!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Well, look now. what pillars there are, with what strength they are built, and of what a thickness.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I don't think that I ever saw handsomer pillars.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I' faith, they were some time since bought by me at such a price!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: aside, whispering. Don't you hear--"They were once"? He seems hardly able to refrain from tears.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: At what price did you purchase them?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I gave three minæ for the two, besides the carriage, He retires to some distance.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: after looking close at them, to TRANIO. Why, upon my word, they are much more unsound than I thought them at first.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Because, i' faith, the woodworm has split them both from the bottom.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I think they were cut at an improper season; that fault damages them; but even as it is, they are quite good enough, if they are covered with pitch. But it was no foreign pulse-eating artisanForeign pulse-eating artisan: From the use of the word "pultiphagus," he probably alludes to Carthaginian workmen, who were very skilful at working in wood. In the Pœnulus, Hanno the Carthaginian is called "patruus pultiphagonides," "the pulse-eating kinsman." If this is the meaning, it is pretty clear that he is not speaking in praise of the workmanship. Some, however, ever, think that as, in early times, the lower classes at Rome lived upon "puls," "pap" or "pottage," the Scene being at Athens, Roman workmen are alluded to; if so, he may mean to speak in praise of the work, and to say that no bungling artists made the doors. See the Note in p. 355. The joints are said to wink, from the close conjunction of the eyelids in the act of winking. did this work. Don't you see the joints in the door? Pointing.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I see them.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Look, how close together they are sleeping.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Sleeping?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: That is, how they wink, I intended to say. Are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: The more I look at each particular, the more it pleases me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: pointing. Don't you see the painting, where one crowWhere one crow: By the "crow," he means himself; and by the "vultures," the two old men. Simo is probably standing at some distance off; and knowing that his master's sight is not good, he feels that he may deride him with impunity. is baffling two vultures? The crow stands there; it's pecking at them both in turn. This way, look, prithee, towards meTowards me: "Ad me." Theuropides thinks he means, "in my direction;" whereas Tranio really means, "look 'at me' and you will see the crow;" though he does not intend that his master shall take it in that sense., that yon may be able to see the crow. THEUROPIDES turns towards him. Now do you see it?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: looking about. For my part, I really see no crow there.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: But do you look in that direction, towards yourselves, since you cannot discover the crow, if perchance you may be able to espy the vultures. THEUROPIDES turns towards SIMO. Now do you see them?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I don't see them.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: But I can see two vultures.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: To make an end of it with you, I don't see any bird at all painted here.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Well then, I give it up. I excuse you; it is through age you cannot see.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: These things which I can see, really they do all please me mightily.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: coming forward. Now, at length, it's worth your while to move further on. THEU. Troth, you give good advice.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: calling at the door. Ho there, boy! take this person round this house and the apartments. But I myself would have shown you round, if I hadn't had business at the Forum.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Away with any one to show me over. I don't want to be shown over. Whatever it is, I'd rather go wrong than any one should show me over.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The house I'm speaking of.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Then I'll go in without any one to show me over.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Go, by all means.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I'll go in-doors, then.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: holding him back. Stop, please; let me see whether the dog----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Very well then, look. TRANIO looks into the passage.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: There is one.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: looking in. Where is it?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: to the dog. Be off and be hanged! 'St, won't you be off to utter perdition with you? What, do you still linger? 'St, away with you from here!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: coming nearer to the door. There's no danger. You only move on. It's as gentleIt's as gentle: This, probably, is intended to refer to the statue of a dog lying down in the vestibule, and not a real one. Pictures of dogs, with "cave canem" written beneath, were sometimes painted on the wall near the door. as a woman in childbed. You may boldly step in-doors wherever you like. I'm going hence to the Forum.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You've acted obligingly. Good speed to you. Exit SIMO. Tranio, come, make that dog move away from the door inside, although it isn't to be feared.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Nay but pointing, you look at it, how gently it lies. Unless you'd like yourself to appear troublesome and cowardly----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Very well, just as you like.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Follow me this way then.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: For my part, I shall not move in any direction from your feet. They go into the house.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: to himself. Servants who, though they are free from fault, still stand in awe of punishment, those same are wont to be serviceable to their masters. But those who fear nothing, after they have merited punishment, hit upon foolish plans for themselves: they exercise themselves in running; they take to flight. But, if they are caught, they acquire from punishment a hoard, which by good means they cannot. They increase from a very little, and from that they lay by a treasure. The resolution that's in my mind is to be determined to be on my guard against punishment, before my back comes to lose its state of soundness. As hitherto it has been, so does it become my hide still to be, without a bruise, and such that I should decline its being beaten. If I have any control over it, I shall keep it well covered upWell covered up: He alludes to the practice of stripping disobedient slaves, for the purpose of flogging them.. When punishment is being showered down on others, don't let it be showered down on me. But as servants wish their master to be, such is he wont to be. He is good to the good, bad to the bad. But now at our house at home there do live so many rogues, lavish of their propertyLavish of their property: That is, of their backs., bearers of stripes. When they are called to go fetch their master, "I shan't go; don't be plaguing me; I know where you are hurrying off to," is the reply. "Now, faith, you mule, you're longing to go to pasturage out of doorsTo pasturage out of doors: This was probably a proverbial, phrase for going to the "thermopolium," the "hot liquor-shop" or "tippling- house," so much frequented by the slaves. See the Trinummus, l. 1013, and the Note to the passage.." With better deserts, this advantage have I reaped from them, and, in consequence, I have come from home. I alone, out of so many servants, am going to fetch my master. When, to-morrow, my master comes to know this, in the morning he will chastise them with bull's-hide spoils. In fine, I care less for their backs than for my own. Much rather shall they be bull's-hide-scourged than I be rope-scourgedBull's-hide-scourged--rope scourged: "Bucædæ--restio." The latter word properly signifies "a ropemaker." The former is probably coined by Plautus.. Moves on.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Hold you and stop this instant. Phaniscus! look round, I say!

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: not turning round. Don't be annoying to me.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Do see how scornful the monkey is!

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I am so for myself; I choose to be. Why do you trouble yourself about it? Walking on.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Are you going to stop this instant, you dirty parasite?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: turning round. How am I a parasite?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you: you can be drawn anywhere by victuals. Do you give yourself airs, because your master's so fond of you?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: rubbing his eyes. O dear, my eyes do acheMy eyes do ache: Phaniscus probably means to say, that the sight of him is as annoying to his eyes as smoke can be..

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Because the smoke's so troublesome.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, will you, you clever workman, who are in the habit of coining money out of leadMoney out of lead: According to Erasmus, (Adagia Chil. v. Cent. 1,) this was a proverbial expression among the Romans, signifying the ability to put on a specious appearance..

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: You cannot compel me to be abusive to you. My master knows me.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Why, really, his own pillowHis own pillow: There is an indelicate allusion in this line; and another turn has been given to it in the Translation. he ought to know, for resting on when drunk.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: If you were sober, you wouldn't be abusive.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Am I to give heed to you, when you won't to me.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: But, you rascal, you come along with me to fetch him.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Troth now, Phaniscus, prithee, do leave off talking about these matters.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I'll do so, and knock at the door. Knocks at the door of the house of THEUROPIDES. Hallo there! is there any person here to protect this door from a most serious injury? Knocking again. Is any one, is any one, I say, coming out here and going to open it? Why, really, no one comes out here. Just as befits such worthless fellows, so they are. But on that account, I've the more need to be cautious that no one may come out and use me ill. They stand aside.

div2.stage: Enter TRANIO and THEUROPIDES, from the house of SIMO.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What's your opinion of this bargain?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I am quite delighted.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Does it seem to you to have been bought too dear?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, I'm sure that I never anywhere saw a house thrown away, this one only excepted.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Does it please you, then?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Does it please me, do you ask me? Why yes, upon my faith, it really does please me very much.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What a fine set of rooms for the women! What a porch!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Exceedingly fine. For my part, I don't think that there is any Porch larger than this in the public buildings.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why, I myself and Philolaches have taken the measure sure of all the porches in the public buildings.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: This is far larger than all of them.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Immortal Gods--a splendid bargain! On my word, if he were now to offer six great talents of silver, ready money, for it, I would never take it.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Upon my faith, if you were inclined to take it, I would never let you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: My money has been well invested upon this purchase.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Boldly confess that by my advice and prompting it was done, who urged him to take up the money of the Banker upon interest, which we paid this person by way of deposit.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You've saved the whole ship. Eighty minæEighty minæ: Forty having been already paid (according to his story) as a deposit, and there being 120 minæ in two talents., you say, are owing for it?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Not a coin more.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: He may have it to-day.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: By all means so, that there may be no dispute arising; or else pay them over to me, I'll then pay them over to him.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: But still, don't let there be any taking me in, if I do give them to you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Could I venture to deceive you in deed or word even in jest only?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Could I venture not to be on my guard against you, so as not to trust anything to you?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why, have I ever imposed upon you in anything, since I was your servant?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: But I've taken good care of that; I owe thanks to myself and my own judgment for that. If I'm only on my guard against you solely, I'm quite wise enough.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: aside. I agree with you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Now be off into the country; tell my son that I've arrived.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I'll do as you wish.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Run with all speed; bid him come to the city at once together with you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Very well. Aside. Now I'll betake myself this way by the back-door to my boon-companions; I'll tell them that things are quiet here, and how I have kept him away from here. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: coming forward. Really, I don't hear either the sound of revellers here, as once it was, nor yet the music-girl singing, nor any one else. Goes towards the door.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What's the matter here? What are these people seeking at my house? What do they want? What are they peeping in for?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I shall proceed to knock at the door. Knocks. Hallo there, unlock the door! Hallo, Tranio! are you going to open it, I say?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: advancing. What story's this, I wonder?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: aloud. Are you going to open it, I say? I've come to fetch my master Callidamates.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Harkye, you lads! what are you doing there? Why are you breaking down that door?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Our master's at a drinking-party here.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Your master at a drinking-party here?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You're carrying the joke too far, my lad.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: We've come to fetch him.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What person?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Our master. Prithee, how often must I tell you?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: There's no one living here my lad; for I do think that you are a decent lad.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Doesn't a young gentleman called Philolaches live in this house?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: aside. This old fellow's crack-brained, surely.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: You are entirely mistaken, respected sirRespected sir: "Pater." Literally, "father."; for unless he moved from here to-day or yesterday, I know for certain that he's living here.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why, no one has been living here for these six months past.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: You are dreaming.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Don't you be impertinent. Let me speak to the lad. Pointing to PHANISCUS.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: No one lives there? O dear----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: It's the fact.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Really! why, yesterday and the day before, four, five, six days ago, all along, in fact, since his father went abroad from here, eating and drinking have never ceased for a single three days here.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: That eating and drinking have never stopped for a single three days here, bringing in wenches, living like Greeks, hiring harpists and music-girls.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Who was it did this?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Philolaches.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What Philolaches?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: He whose father I take to be Theuropides.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: apart. O dear, O dear! I'm utterly undone, if he says the truth in this. I'll continue to question him still Do you say that this Philolaches, whoever he is, has been in the habit of drinking here together with your master?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Here, I tell you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: My lad, contrary to your appearance, you are a fool. See now, please, that you've not perchance been dropping in somewhere for an afternoon's whetAn afternoon's whet: "Merendam." According to some, this meal was the same as the "prandium," or "breakfast;" while others take it to have been a slight meal or luncheon, taken at about four or five in the afternoon., and have been drinking there a little more than was enough.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Just what I say: don't be going by mistake to other persons' houses.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I know where I ought to go, and the place to which I was to come. Philolaches lives here, whose father is Theuropides; and who, after his father went away to trade, made free a music-girl here.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Philolaches, say you?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Just so; Philematium, I mean.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: For how much?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: For thirty talents.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: No, by ApolloNo, by Apollo: Ma to\n *)apo/llw. He uses a Greek adjuration; you mean minæ.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Do you say that a mistress was purchased for Philolaches for thirty minæ?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I do say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: And that he gave her her freedom?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I do say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: And that after his father had departed hence abroad, he has been carousing here continually with your master?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I do say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Well, has he made purchase of the house next door here?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I don't say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Has he given forty minæ, too, to this person, to be as a deposit?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Nor yet do I say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Ah me! you've proved my ruin!

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Aye, and he has proved the ruin of his father.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You prophesy the truth! I could wish it false!

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: A friend of his father, I suppose?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Ah me! Upon my faith, you do pronounce him to be a wretched father.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Why really, this is nothing at all-thirty minæ, in comparison with the other expenses he has incurred in good living. He has ruined his father. There's one servant there a very great scoundrel, Tranio by name; he could even waste the revenue of a HerculesThe revenue of a Hercules: It was the custom with many to devote to Hercules the tenth part of their possessions. Consequently, the revenues belonging to the Temples of this Deity would be especially large.. On my word, I'm sadly distrest for his father; for when he comes to know that things have gone on thus, a hot coal will be scorching his breast, poor man.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: If, indeed, this is the truth.

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: What am I to gain, that I should tell a lie? Knocks again at the door. Hallo, you! is any one coming to open this door?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER SERVANT of Callidamates.
sp.p: Why do you knock in this way, when there's no one in the house?

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: I fancy that he's gone elsewhere to carouse. Now then, let's begone. They move as if going.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What, my lad, are you off then? Liberty's the overcoat for your backThe overcoat for your back: Schmieder thinks this is said insultingly to Phaniscus. It would, however, appear otherwise: Phaniscus having no "pænnla," or "overcoat," on, Theuropides, who thinks him a very worthy fellow, says, "My good fellow, your freedom would make yon a very fine overcoat.".

sp.speaker: PHANISCUS
sp.p: Nothing have I with which to cover my back, except to pay respect and service to my master. (Exeunt PHANISCUS and SERVANT.)

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p:
to himself. By my troth, I am undone! What need is there of talking? According to the words I have heard, I surely haven't lately voyaged hence to Ægypt, but even to some desolate land and the most remote shores have I been borne about, so much am I at a loss to know where I now am. But I shall soon know; for see, here's the person of whom my son bought the house.
Enter SIMO.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What are you about?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm coming home from the Forum.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Has anything new been going on at the Forum to-day?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why yes.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What is it, pray?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I saw a dead man being carried to burial.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Dear me! that is something new!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I saw one who was dead being carried out to burialBeing carried out to burial: It is supposed that in this reply he plays upon the question of Theuropides, who uses the word "processit" in his question, which may either mean, "what has been going on?" or "what procession has there been? They said that he had been alive but just before.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Woe to that head of yours for your nonsense!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why are you, thus idling about, enquiring after the news?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Because I've just arrived from abroad.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm engaged out to dine: don't suppose I shall invite youI shall invite you: He alludes to the universal custom of giving friends a "cœna viatica' or welcome entertainment, on arriving from. off a journey..

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, I don't want.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: But, to-morrow, unless any person invites me first, I'll even dine with you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, and that, too, I don't want. Unless you are engaged with something of greater importance, lend me your attention.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You have received, as far as I understand, forty minæ of Philolaches.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Never a coin, so far as I know.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What? Not from my servant Tranio?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Much less is that the case.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Which he gave you by way of deposit?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What are you dreaming about?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What, I? Why, really, 'tis yourself, who hope that, by dissembling in this manner, you'll be able to make void this bargain.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: The business that, in my absence, my son transacted with you here.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How did your son, in your absence, transact any business with me? What pray, or on what day?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I owe you eighty minæ of silver.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Not to me, indeed, upon my faith; but still, if you do owe them, give them me. Faith must be kept. Don't be attempting to deny it.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Assuredly, I shall not deny that I owe them; and I shall pay them. Do you take care how you deny that you received the forty from him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, look this way at me, and answer me. He said that you were wishful to give a wife to your son; for that reason, he said that you intended building on your own premises.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I, intended building here?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: So he told me.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Ah me! I'm ruined outright! I've hardly any voice leftI've hardly any voice left: "Vocis on habeo satis." Lietally 'I have not voice enough.". Neighbours, I'm undone, ruined quite!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Has Tranio been causing any confusion?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Yes; he has thrown everything into confusion. He has made a fool of me to-day in a disgraceful manner.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: This matter is just as I am telling you: he has this day made a fool of me in an outrageous manner. Now I beseech you that you'll kindly aid me, and lend me your assistance.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I beg of you, come this way together with me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Be it so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Lend me the assistance of your slaves and some scourges.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Take them by all means.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: At the same time I'll tell you about this, in what a fashion he has this day imposed upon me. They go into the house of SIMO.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: to himself. The man that shall prove timid in critical matters, will not be worth a nutshell. And, really, to say what that expression, "worth a nutshell," means, I don't know. But after my master sent me into the country to fetch his son hither, I went that way pointing slily through the lane to our garden. At the entrance to the garden that's in the lane, I opened the door; and by that road I led out all the troop, both men and women. After, from being in a state of siege, I had led out my troops to a place of safety, I adopted the plan of convoking a senate of my comrades, and when I had convoked it, they forthwith banished me from the senate. When I myself perceived that the matter must be decided by my own judgment, as soon as ever I could, I did the same as many others do, whose affairs are in a critical or a perplexed state; they proceed to render them more perplexed, so that nothing can be settled. But I know full well, that now by no means can this be concealed from the old man. But how's this, that our next neighbour's door makes a noise? Why, surely this is my master: I'd like to have a taste of his talk. Goes aside, out of sight of THEUROPIDES. house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: in the doorway, speaking to SIMO'S SLAVES. Do you stand there, in that spot within the threshold; so that, the very instant I call, you may sally forth at once. Quickly fasten the handcuffs upon him. I'll wait before the house for this fellow that makes a fool of me, whose hide I'll make a fool of in fine style, if I live.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: apart. The affair's all out. Now it's best for you, Tranio, to consider what you are to do.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: to himself. I must go to work to catch him cleverly and artfully when he comes here. I'll not disclose to him my feelings all at once; I'll throw out my line; I'll conceal the fact that I know anything of these matters.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: apart. O cunning mortal! not another person in Athens can be pronounced more clever than he. One can no more this day deceive him than he can a stone. I'll accost the man; I'll address him.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: to himself. Now I do wish that he would come here.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: apart. I' faith, if me indeed you want, here I am ready at hand for you. Comes forward.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Bravo! Tranio, what's being done?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: The country people are coming from the country Philolaches will be here in a moment.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, he comes opportunely for me. This neighbour of ours I take to be a shameless and dishonest fellow.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Inasmuch as he denies that he knows you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Denies it?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: And declares that you never gave him a single coin of money

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Out with you, you are joking me, I do believe; he doesn't deny it.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I am sure now that you are joking; for surely he doesn't deny it.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Nay but, upon my faith, he really does deny it; or that he has sold this house to Philolaches.

sp.speaker: TEA.
sp.p: Well now, pray, has he denied that the money was paid him?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Nay more, he offered to take an oath to me, if I desired it, that he had neither sold this house, nor had any money him paid been. I told him the same that you told me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: He offered to give up all his servants for examination.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Nonsense! On my faith, he never will give them up.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: He really does offer them.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why then, do you summon him to trial.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Wait a bit; I'll make trial as I fancy. I'm determined on it.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Bring the fellow here to me.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What then, if I go fetch some men?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: It ought to have been done already; or else bid the young man to demand possession of the house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why no, I want to do this first--to put the servants under examinationServants under examination: "Quæstioni." "Examination by torture;" which was the method used by the Romans for extracting confessions from slaves..

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I' faith, I think it ought to be done. Meantime, I'll take possession of this altarTake possession of this altar: When a person took refuge at an altar, he could not be brought to justice, or have violence offered to his person. According to some writers, there were always two altars on the stage of Comedy, one on the right hand, sacred to Apollo, and one on the left, devoted o that Divinity or Hero in honor of whom the Play was being acted..Runs to the altar.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: You can understand nothing. Why, that those may not be able to take refuge here whom he shall give up for examination, I'll keep guard here for you; so that the examination may not come to nothing.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Get up from the altar.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Prithee, don't you take possession of the altar.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You shall hear; why, because I especially want this, for them to be taking refuge there. Do let them; so much the more easily shall I get him fined before the judge.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What you intend to do, do it. Why do you wish to sow further strife? You don't know how ticklish a thing it is to go to law.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Just get up, beckoning this way; it's, then, to ask your advice upon something that I want you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Still, as I am, I'll give my advice from this spot: my wits are much sharper when I'm sittingsSharper when I'm sitting: Warner suggests that a little raillery is intended here, upon the custom of sitting when dispensing justice and paying adoration to the Gods.. Besides, advice is given with higher sanction from holy placesWith higher sanction from holy places: The ancients made use of sacred places for the purpose of debating on affairs of importance in, as being likely to add weight and authority to their judgment. The Roman Senate often met in the Temples, and there administered justice and gave audience to ambassadors..

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Get up; don't be trifling. Just look me in the face.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: looking at him. I am looking.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Do you see me?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I do see--that if any third person were to step in here, he would die of hunger.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Because he would get no profit; for, upon my faith, we are both artful ones.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You have deceived me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: How so, pray?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You've wiped me cleanYou've wiped me clean: "Emungo," "to wipe the nose" for a person, also meant "to cheat" or "impose upon him;" probably, by reason of the state of helplessness it implied in the party who was so treated..

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Consider, please, if it wasn't well done; is your nose running still?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Aye, all my brains besides have you been wiping out of my head as well. For all your villanies I have discovered from their very roots; and not from the roots, indeed, i' faith, but even from beneath the very roots. Never this day, by my troth, will you have planned all this without being punished. I shall at once, you villain, order fire and faggotsOrder fire and faggots: Though a suppliant could not be removed from the altar by force, still it was allowable to burn him away, by surrounding him with fire. to be placed around you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Don't do it; for it's my way to be sweeter boiled than roasted.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I'll make an example of you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Because I please you, you select me for an example.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Say now: what kind of a person did I leave my son, when I went away from here?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: One with feet and hands, with fingers, ears, eyes, and lips.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I asked you something else than that.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: For that reason I now answer you something else. But look, I see Callidamates, the friend of your son, coming this way. Deal with me in his presence, if you want anything

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: to himself. When I had buried all drowsinessBuried all drowsiness: Generally we hear of a person "being buried in sleep;" but Callidamates considers that a drunkard, when he awakes from his sleep, "buries slumber." It is not unlike the words of Shakspeare, in Macbeth: "Macbeth doth murder sleep!", and slept off the debauch, Philolaches told me that his father had arrived here from abroad; in what a way too his servant had imposed upon the man on his arrival; he said that he was afraid to come into his presence. Now of our company I am deputed sole ambassador, to obtain peace from his father. And look, most opportunely here he is. Accosting THEUROPIDES. I wish you health, Theuropides, and am glad that you've got back safe from abroad. You must dine here with us to-day. Do so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Callidamates, may the Gods bless you. For your dinner I offer you my thanks.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Will you come then?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: To THEUROPIDES. Do promise him; I'll go for you, if you don't like.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Whip-scoundrel, laughing at me still?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What, because I say that I'll go to dinner for you?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: But you shan't go. I'll have you carried to the cross, as you deserve.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Come, let this pass, and say that I shall go to the dinner. Why are you silent?

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: to TRANIO. But why, you greatest of simpletons, have you taken refuge at the altar?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: He frightened me on his arrival. To THEUROPIDES. Say now, what I have done amiss. Look, now there's an umpire for us both; come, discuss the matter.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I say that you have corrupted my son.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Only listen. I confess that he has done amiss; that he has given freedom to his mistress; that in your absence he has borrowed money at interest; that, I admit, is squandered away. Has he done anything different to what sons of the noblest families do?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I must be on my guard with you; you are too clever a pleader.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Just let me be umpire in this matter. TO TRANIO. Get up; I'll seat myself there.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: By all means: take the management of this dispute to yourself. Pushes him to one side of the altar.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why, this is surely a trick. Make me, then, not to be in a fright, and yourself to be in a fright in my stead.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I consider now everything of trifling consequence, compared with the way in which he has fooled me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I' faith, 'twas cleverly done, and I rejoice that it was done. Those who have white heads ought at that age to be wiser.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What am I now to do if my friend Demipho or Philonides----

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Tell them in what way your servant made a fool of you. You would be affording most capital plots for Comedies.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Hold your tongue awhile; let me speak in my turn.--Listen.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: In the first place of all then, you know that I am the companion of your son; he has gone to my house, for he is ashamed to come into your presence, because he knows that you are aware what he has done. Now, I beseech you, do pardon his simplicity and youthfulness. He is your son; you know that this age is wont to play such pranks; whatever he has.done, he has done in company with me. We have acted wrong: the interest, principal, and all the sum at which the mistress was purchased, all of it we will find, and will contribute together, at our own cost, not yours.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: No mediator could have come to me more able to influence me than yourself. I am neither angry with himNeither angry with him: "Illi," "with him;" evidently meaning Philolaches., nor do I blame him for anything: nay more, in my presence, wench on, drink, do what you please. If he's ashamed of this, that he has been extravagant, I have sufficient satisfaction.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: I'm quite ashamed myself

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: He grants pardon thus far; now then, what is to become of me?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Filth, tied up as you hang, you shall be beaten with stripes.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Even though I am ashamedThough I am ashamed: This piece of impudence is very characteristic of Tranio.?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I'll be the death of you, if I live!

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Make this pardon general; do, pray, forgive Tranio this offence, for my sake.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I would more readily put up with your obtaining any other request of me than that I should forbear sending to perdition this fellow for his most villanous doings.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Pray, do pardon him.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Do pardon me?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Look there, don't you see how the villain sticks there? Pointing to the altar.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Tranio, do be quiet, if you are in your senses.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Only do you be quiet in urging this matter. I'll subdue him with stripes, so that he shall be quiet.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Really, there is no need. Come now, do allow yourself to be prevailed upon.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I wish you would not request me.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Troth now, I do entreat you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I wish you would not request me, I tell you.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: It's in vain you wish me not; only do grant this one pardon for his offence, pray, for my sake, I do entreat you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why make this difficulty? As if to-morrow I shouldn't be very soon committing some other fault; then, both of them, both this one and that, you'll be able to punish soundly.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Do let me prevail upon you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Well then, have it so; begone, unpunished! TRANIO jumps down from the altar. There now, pointing to CALLIDAMATES return him thanks for it. Coming forward. Spectators, this Play is finished; grant us your applauseGrant us your applause: We may here remark that The Intriguing Chambermaid, one of Fielding's comedies, is founded upon this entertaining Play..
